title: Are electric cars going to replace gas cars? - Quora

response.answer_text: Considering that the UK is considering banning the sale of new petrol and diesel vehicles by 2040, I would definitely say yes. However: (I must warn you, I’ll incite a war by saying this against two types of people who, if I’m honest, are ignorant to their own causes most of the time hence my explanation below): Battery (BEV) and Hydrogen Fuel Cell (HCF) vehicles are all ‘electric vehicles’ (use a medium to convert to electricity to drive a motor) but people ‘don’t see’ the benefits of both right now, which I believe is distrupting the pace of how quick we can change to EVs which either way, is definitely considered better for the environment and also our airways (NOx emissions and soot etc) As people had said before, the pace of change in battery technology means we can have longer range BEVs (>200 miles) and with mass production also increasing rapidly (think Gigafactory), we can also reduce the $/kWh as well meaning affordable vehicles on the masses. These vehicles will be perfect for the vast majority of commuters which only need a vehicle for A to B, as well as mostly replacing ICE vehicles as long as the charging infrastructure However, I still believe that some people are not seeing the clear advantage of HCF vehicles being within product lineups: the ease of refuelling. I see this being a clear advantage to HGVs, business drivers etc which, I understand in niche applications such as taxi companies that current BEVs do work, that the ‘5 minute fuel up’ is certainly the main reason why people, at the moment, will not buy a BEV. with HCF you can, and probably always will be able to do whereas with current charging infrastructure, this is quite difficult, if not impossible. Current charging standards like Chademo provide 50kW and CCS provides up to 100kW which at full speed (unlikely achieved during the entire charge session) would mean a Leaf or the Ioniq would take, at a minimum, 25 minutes or so. There are talks to boost this up to 300kW however at that point the grid infrastructure would need to be looked into more carefully when one car charging is the equivalent to 150 kettles. Just to clarify, I’m not trying to discredit BEVs, I personally want to be a part of the development of them because I can see it geniunely is the future for the vast majority but what I’m trying to say is, sometimes society does become blind about the options we have and ‘putting all our eggs in one basket’ is not the optimum solution. Sorry for my lengthy explanation, I thought it would be benefitial to at least include the alternatives if I was going to say EVs will replace gas vehicles.

Absolutely. And it’ll happen quicker than most people realize. Battery Electric Vehicles (BEV) are much simpler than Internal Combustion Engine (ICE) vehicles. Your typical ICE has about 2000 moving parts. A BEV has about 100 moving parts. With a BEV, there’s no oil or lubricant to worry about; the only fluid that needs replacing is windshield washer. There’s no gas tank; instead, the batteries lie in a “skateboard” configuration along the bottom of the car, lowering the center of gravity and making the car much safer. BEVs have more storage and more room for passengers. ICE vehicles are only about 20–30% efficient (conversion of potential energy to actual power); the rest is lost as heat. BEVs are more than 80% efficient, which more than makes up for the lower energy density of a battery compared to petrol combustion. BEVs have linear acceleration since there’s no gearbox or clutch or shifting from one gear ratio to another. They have regenerative braking to recharge the batteries. They need almost no servicing or maintenance (which is going to radically change the car dealership model.) With all the research going into battery technologies, the price of batteries is steadily decreasing. Tesla is already reporting manufacturing costs below what some experts were predicting in 5–10 years. Battery degradation is basically a non-issue. Tesla Model S owners typically report 1–2% degradation in the first year, then maybe a ½% per year after that. After 10 years, the batteries should have well over 90% of their original capacity if properly cared for (which is easy.) There are Tesla taxis in Europe that have already driven over 300,000 miles with no problems whatsoever. And the batteries themselves are 99% recyclable. Beyond passenger cars, dozens of companies are working on other vehicle types from electric buses with enough power to run all day, to short haul delivery trucks, to long haul Class 8 semi-tractor trailers, to heavy mining machinery. All of them will eventually be electrified. Some people still claim that BEVs pollute the same as petrol and diesel vehicles because coal and natural gas fire the power plants used to generate electricity. But this is a straw man for two main reasons: first, it ignores the fuel needed to deliver petrol and diesel to gas and refueling stations, which is not required for electricity being delivered to chargers. Second, it ignores the accelerating movement to close coal and natural gas plants and switch to solar and wind power, including storage technologies to handle peak loads. All these reasons explain why almost every car manufacturer is rolling out BEV plans and concepts, why major cities are moving to ban the use of ICE vehicles on certain days and times, and why major countries are looking to ban the sale of ICE vehicles in the next 10–20 years. And switching to BEVs across the board, and to solar and wind power for generation, will be a primary driver for reducing human-caused climate change and finally taking control of global warming. With the current exception of the US, every country realizes what a serious problem is global warming, and how clean energy offers a straightforward solution to these problems. People don’t realize what a major sea change this is. The internal combustion engine has reached the end of its useful life; there’s no way to make it significantly more efficient, cheaper, easier to manufacture, less polluting (without cheating; see “VW Dieselgate”) and more reliable. BEV technology beats ICE on every one of these evaluation criteria.

I would say without a doubt. Will it take time? Yes. But already more and more electrification is being added to the drivetrains of various vehicles and the components of the internal combustion engine are getting more and more complex to meet government efficiency requirements and remain competitive on efficiency with competing technologies. This adds to the cost, while the main cost driver for electric vehicles, the battery, has been on a steady decline. It is said that when the cost of Li-ion batteries falls below about $100/kWh that EVs will be on cost parity with internal combustion engines. Then economics will take over. The most recent cost we’ve seen quoted is $145/kWh for the batteries in the Chevy BoltEV. Just 6 years ago when the first mainstream EVs started to hit the road, costs were in the $350–400/kWh range, so you can get an idea of how fast they are falling. You will probably be able to continue to buy gas vehicles, but they will cost more to buy, cost more to operate, cost more to maintain. Once this tipping point happens, the demand for the lower cost alternative will drive dealers, and carmakers, to provide the lower cost alternative. Also keep in mind that some cities have already banned ICE vehicles from certain districts, and entire COUNTRIES are moving towards banning gas vehicles in the future: Norway by 2025; The Netherlands by 2025; Germany by 2030; India by 2030. While these plans may not come to fruition on those timelines, the trend certainly is towards the end of the gasoline era.

“Keeping in mind that electric cars are prone to catching fire; will electric cars ever replace gasoline or diesel powered cars?” Let’s start by evaluating the statement that prefaces your question. Here’s a helpful article from CNN that provides some data that refutes your assertion: Are electric cars more likely to catch fire? Per the article, based on data on Teslas, the rate of fires is 5 per billion miles traveled, vs. 55 per billion miles traveled in gasoline cars. Admittedly, the number of miles traveled in gasoline cars is orders of magnitude higher, so there are probably pretty big error bars around the electric car numbers, but the early data points to EV’s being at least no more likely to catch fire than gasoline cars. Beyond that, as the article goes on to explain, gas fires are typically more dangerous than battery fires. Battery fires tend to start slow, and will always start in the battery, whereas fuel fires can result when fuel leaks onto other surfaces, or even (in the case of gasoline) from vapors reaching an ignition source. While both kinds of fire are equally destructive to the vehicle, battery fires typically give occupants more time to notice the fire and escape. If there is a downside, it’s that a driver might park an EV in his or her garage not knowing that the battery is damaged, and have a fire erupt inside the garage later. In conclusion, fire risk is certainly not a disincentive for adoption of EV’s, and may over the long term help drive adoption and even save lives.
